Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Leaving a package safely at the doorstep when no one is home
Story: I stared at my phone, my mother’s message glowing on the screen: “Don’t forget, you’re leading the prayer at the family ceremony tonight. It means a lot to your grandmother.” My heart thudded with the weight of her words. Being the eldest daughter, I was expected to carry on our traditions, to show respect and devotion. But as I glanced at the stack of packages in my car, my work phone buzzed with a new delivery notification—urgent, no rescheduling allowed. The address was across town, and the recipient had left strict instructions: “Do not leave the package unattended.” My supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind, reminding me of the company’s zero-tolerance policy for failed deliveries. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between my family’s expectations and my job’s demands. My hands trembled as I gripped the steering wheel, my mind racing with the impossible choice ahead.
